description: From Latin cotylēdōn, from Ancient Greek κοτυληδών (kotulēdṓn, “cup-shaped cavity”), from κοτύλη (kotúlē, “cup”).

entries.meaning: (physiology) Each of the patches of villi on the foetal chorion in the placenta of ruminants and some other mammals.
examples: Forced to apply animal findings to humans, his human womb also had cotyledons like a dog's.

entries.meaning: (botany) The leaf of the embryo of a seed-bearing plant; after germination it becomes the first leaves of the seedling.
